subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quikscript extensions to Shavian (or separate script)
msgSnippet: ... That s satisfactory, since QS users learn the unligatured forms first anyway, like U.S. kids learning printing (unligatured handwriting) before script.
messageBody:
Michael Everson scripsit:

> I have some good passages in Shavian. I can convert one into QS but
> it will not have many ligatures.

That's satisfactory, since QS users learn the unligatured forms first
anyway, like U.S. kids learning printing (unligatured handwriting) before
script. The only ligatures given on the Read chart (in the Quikscript
Alphabet and Manual) are Ye+Ooze and Eight+Roe. The Tremblay chart
(shown at the Wikipedia article) gives these, but also gives ligatures
for Earth, Are, Or, Ear.

The Read chart uses the names Pea, Bay, Tea, ..., which your proposal
adopts; the Tremblay chart uses the names Pipe, Bob, Tut, ... in Shavian
style. Having two sets of letter names is rather annoying, but perhaps
it should be recognized in the official Unicode names if the scripts are
disunified, since both sets are in current use. This would be analogous
to the naming system used for Runic, so QUIKSCRIPT LETTER PEA PIPE,
like RUNIC LETTER FEHU FEOH FE F. It makes it easier for people used
to one set of names to find the letter they want.

The relevant passages from WG2 N1417, the Runic proposal, are as follows:

[section 2, p. 2]

The idea of the compromise proposal is to include in the ISO
character name both the original names of a rune in the different
Runic writing systems and the name used in modern scholarship.
These names should satisfy the needs of all the diverse user
communities for runes. It has been possible to choose character
names of this kind which do not exceed 38 characters.

[section 6, pp. 4-5]

For the Runic letters, the Designation part [i.e. everything after
"RUNIC LETTER"] consists of one or more components, separated
by spaces. Each of these reflects the name of the rune as
used in one of those Runic writing systems where a full system
of rune names was used (primitive runes, Anglo-Frisian runes,
and Viking Age Nordic runes, taken in this order). The last
of the components, in some cases the only component, indicates
the rune name used in modern scholarship. In a few cases some
of these names are identical. They are then not repeated in
the proposed character name.

> I'm not a reader/writer of QS.

Which suggests that they are not mutually legible!

By the same token, I don't read Coptic either, but even I can see from
your specimen that Coptic looks more like Cyrillic than like Greek.
